Award.AwardTitle: Waveguide QED: Quantum Optics of Multiple Two-Level-Systems Strongly Coupled to 1D Bosons
Award.AbstractNarration:
Strong interaction between light and matter leads both to novel physical phenomena and to new quantum information processing capabilities. The main systems showing such strong interactions to date are difficult to scale and connect together. In this work, a new, open, scalable system with strong interactions is studied theoretically: a one-dimensional waveguide interacting with one or several quantum systems. The quantum systems cause the photons in the waveguide to become entangled and correlated, generating a new kind of multi-photon bound state. The many effects of these bound states are being investigated, such as the associated photon blockade. Their use for quantum communication, and in particular for the cryptography task known as quantum key distribution, are being evaluated.

This project substantially impacts two broader fields. First, nanoscale photonic devices often involve such waveguides and quantum systems as building blocks. The new physical effects studied here are leading to a better understanding of such elements and may lead to qualitatively new devices. Second, the emerging paradigm of "quantum networks" involves elements that look exactly like the waveguide systems proposed here. Training a junior researcher is a key impact of this project: a graduate student is involved in all aspects and so is thoroughly trained in many-body and quantum optics theory as well as potential nano-photonics and quantum information applications. Finally, the co-PIs are involved in outreach in the local schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the main themes of contemporary atomic and condensed matter physics is the investigation of correlations between particles, especially ones that arise from fundamental quantum mechanical principles. In this regard, a two-level-system (qubit) coupled to a bosonic mode, representing an atom coupled to a photon field, has been a paradigm of quantum electrodynamics. The key to achieving interesting and potentially useful effects is to have strong coupling between the qubit and the bosons, which is usually done using a cavity. Recently, however, several experimental approaches have been proposed to obtain strong coupling without a cavity. In this project, we focused on two-level-systems strongly coupled to a one-dimensional (1D) bosonic field, a subject dubbed "Waveguide QED." 
      Waveguide QED involves new physical effects, which may then have practical implications such as for quantum information or nanophotonic devices. The most dramatic new effect is the creation of bound states of photons: upon scattering off a qubit, two free photons may emerge in a wavefunction in which their relative coordinate is exponentially localized. Thus, the qubit has generated an effective interaction between the photons, highly unusual as photons are normally non-interacting. 
      Waveguide QED is being actively pursued experimentally in a wide variety of systems: traditional atomic physics ones such as a single atom near a nano fiber, quantum dots coupled to plasmonic or photonic crystal waveguides, and the recently developed novel system of superconducting qubits coupled to a microwave transmission line. 
      In this project, we theoretically studied the correlations among photons produced by strong coupling. Our accomplishments include:
(i) Finding correlations produced in a coherent state wavepacket. Characterizing this non-classical light and showing how multi-photon content is suppressed 
(ii) Developing a new more efficient method for studying waveguide QED. 
(iii) Carrying out the first study of multiple qubits connected to the waveguide. Characterizing the increase and development of the correlations produced in the photon field as the number of qubits varies from one to ten. 

      With regard to Broader Impacts, a key contribution is the training of students: this research was carried out by two graduate students (in sequence) and one undergraduate. The graduate students were involved in all aspects and so were well-trained in many-body and quantum optics theory as well as potential nanophotonic and quantum information applications. The results of this project may substantially impact two broader fields. First, nanophotonic devices often involve qubits and 1D modes as building blocks. The new physical effects studied here would certainly lead to a better understanding of such elements and may lead to qualitatively new devices. Second, quantum networks involve elements that look exactly like the qubit+1D-bosons system studied here. Such nonlinear phenomena in open systems can play a critical role in the manipulation of individual, mobile quanta, which is a key goal of quantum information processing and communication.
